City of Chillicothe

Located only fifteen miles north of Peoria is historic Chillicothe, where the rails cross the river. This town grew from its river traffic and ideal location for railroad transportation. The flourishing downtown business district is classic Main Street USA playing home to boutiques, restaurants, barbershops and the Town Theater. 

Chillicothe’s Town Theatre is located in a reclaimed opera house dating back to 1920. After the opera house suffered a catastrophic fire in 1922, the site sat empty until 1926 when it was purchased and reopened as the Sunset Theatre in 1927. After several incarnations and another fire in 1982, the theater is now owned by the Chillicothe Optimist Club. Most notable in this river town is the yearly Summer Camp Music Festival. This multi-day music festival at Three Sisters Park brings more than 30,000 visitors to the town of 6,000 residents every Memorial Day Weekend.

Don't miss Illinois Made maker Triple Dipple's in downtown, where you are encouraged to "eat dessert first!"
Chillicothe Events

City of East Peoria

A quick drive across the Illinois River takes you to East Peoria, where entertainment is never in short supply. Home to the famous Festival of Lights, this marvel of engineering creates giant floats and scenes made entirely of Christmas lights! 

Enjoy live casino action at the Par-A-Dice Hotel Casino and choose from over 900 slot machines, 30 table games and live poker. Par-A-Dice also offers fine dining at Boyd’s Steakhouse or more casual dining at Options Buffet, Nelson’s Deli, and Bourbon’s. Try the all-new Tin Lizard Bar & Grill, the go-to spot for good drinks, great food and the best local and regional bands.

Discover the numerous shopping and dining options in the ever-growing Levee District. Experience any hunter’s paradise at Bass Pro Shops complete with a 26,000-gallon freshwater aquarium and enjoy a game of bowling with dinner at Uncle Buck’s Fishbowl.

Looking for information about this year's Red, White and BOOM? Check out our annual events page for up-to-date information about this year's event.

City of Elmwood

Enjoy small-town magic and historic charm when you visit picturesque Elmwood. Have a bite to eat at our amazing restaurants, take in a movie and experience the Palace Theater or join us for one of our amazing festivals on the square. Spend a summer evening listening to one of the oldest municipal bands sending beautiful tunes through Central Park where you will find, Lorado Taft's sculpture "The Pioneers", a gift to his hometown. Experience two museums dedicated to Lorado Taft and Elmwood's rich history or take in our newly painted murals. Whatever you decide to do in Elmwood will be a memorable experience that leaves you craving that hometown feel.

Elmwood Strawberry Festival

Held on the first Saturday of June in Elmwood, Illinois. Central Park at the corner of Main and Magnolia is filled with crafters and vendors, as well as great food including lots of strawberry desserts and local entertainers.

Learn More

Village of Morton

Welcome to the Pumpkin Capital of the World! The Village of Morton is home to Nestle USA, maker of the world’s top-selling canned pumpkin, Libby’s Pumpkin. What holiday dinner is complete without a pumpkin pie made from Libby’s? This quaint, peaceful village is rapidly building its image as an up-and-coming foodie destination. 

Try Kemp 208 for a relaxed, family-friendly dining experience while staying true to a modern perspective and an intricate focus to detail. Boasting an upscale menu, Kemp 208 brings the freshest ingredients to the food they serve, along with a dynamic wine, beer and spirits collection. Or grab some friends and visit Seasons Gastropub for an eclectic menu and a seemingly endless beer, wine and cocktail list. Seasons is the perfect place to enjoy a breezy summer night with live music on their outdoor patio. For a more classy, upscale option, try Ūnum Fine Wine & Whiskey Lounge.  Sip their artisan cocktails inspired by the prohibition era while you marvel at their entrancing backlit wine wall.

The 2021 Morton Pumpkin Festival - Pumpkins, Tailgates, & Traditions

While the 2021 Morton Pumpkin Festival will be a little different than in past years, we're all still excited to honor fall traditions and attend the 55th Pumpkin Festival: Pumpkins, Tailgates, & Traditions. The official dates for Pumpkins, Tailgates, & Traditions are Wednesday, September 15 - Saturday, September 18. Head over to the Morton Pumpkin Festival's website for more info and stay tuned for a schedule of events!

The events will be reimagined using the Restore Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity guidelines and with the input of the Tazewell County Health Department, Village of Morton and Morton Police Department. This is a continually evolving situation and the festival is following local, state and federal guidelines to ensure the safety of our community and guests. Please be respectful of other individuals and families and please follow the guidelines that are listed for the event to make a fun and safe experience for everyone involved.

City of Pekin

The Marigold Capital of the World is filled with unique attractions to explore. Home to the world’s largest sundial, you can spend the day in Mineral Springs Park paddle boating on the lagoon. Enjoy a world-class golf course, Pekin Paintball Park, disc golf, bowling and Dragonland Water Park. Take a stroll downtown on historic Court Street and enjoy an abundance of shopping and delicious dining!

City of Peoria

Welcome to Peoria, the largest city on the Illinois River. Formerly the Whiskey Capital of the World, Peoria found its new identity after Prohibition decimated the distilleries. Hometown to Caterpillar Inc., Peoria made a new name for itself in the manufacturing industry. Today, innovators like AutonomouStuff are leading central Illinois into the future of automation.  While the circumstances may change, the fierce spirit of Peoria endures. 

Don’t miss the Peoria Riverfront Museum, the only multidisciplinary museum of its kind in the U.S. This museum offers major exhibitions, a dome planetarium, a giant screen theater and interactive displays for all ages. Or visit the Caterpillar Visitors Center and learn the story of how this manufacturing giant came to be. Take a virtual ride in the bed of a massive two-and-a-half-story Cat 797F Mining Truck. Enjoy interactive exhibits like designing your own Cat machine and see what it’s like to operate heavy machinery as the pros do! Peoria’s strong history in sports is evident with over 10 golf courses to choose from, hockey with the Peoria Rivermen or baseball with the Peoria Chiefs, a Class A St. Louis Cardinals affiliate.  Hungry? The dining options in Peoria are endless. Enjoy delicious pub food and craft beer at Obed & Isaac’s Microbrewery located in a renovated church constructed in 1889. Or try Thyme Kitchen + Craft Beer, a gastropub with unique food options and an extensive drink menu. 

Whiskey. Manufacturing. Sports. Automation. Past, present and future, this is Peoria.

Village of Peoria Heights

Eat•Shop•Play
Uniquely Boutique

Nestled on the west bluffs of the Illinois River, the Village of Peoria Heights possesses City convenience with Village charm.

It is home to a thriving downtown business district that hosts over seventy-five eclectic and independently owned retail stores and restaurants.

Peoria Heights is famous for Tower Park which hosts a one-of-a-kind 200 ft. observation tower. The tower provides gorgeous panoramic views of the village, the Illinois River Valley and its surrounding areas.

Being home to Forest Park Nature Center, the Rock Island Greenway, and Grandview Drive makes Peoria Heights perfect for any active lifestyle.

Teddy Roosevelt named Grandview Drive the “World’s Most Beautiful Drive” in 1910 for a reason, as it has the most breathtaking views of the river and many historic and remarkable estates lining it.

We invite you to explore this quaint Village; you will feel right at home in the thriving and artsy community.

Village of Princeville 

Located Northwest of Peoria, the Village of Princeville is a friendly, safe and diverse community with a strong sense of family. The Village of Princeville is constantly growing, and there's plenty to do there making it a great place for visitors to spend their time.

Rock Island Trail

Read More

Princeville Heritage Museum

The Princeville Heritage Museum features area artifacts, antique agriculture equipment, a genealogy research area, and much more.

Read More

slides.description: The Princeville Heritage Museum features area artifacts, antique agriculture equipment, a genealogy research area, and much more.
slides.title: Princeville Heritage Center

widgets.html:
Cutter's Grove

Cutter’s Grove is the largest park in Princeville. The semi-wooded area boasts a fully lighted baseball field for evening & nighttime games. Covered picnic areas make for great family reunion locations or large gatherings, a perfect spot for a family outing.

Read More

slides.description: Cutter’s Grove is the largest park in Princeville. The semi-wooded area boasts a fully lighted baseball field for evening & nighttime games. Covered picnic areas make for great family reunion locations or large gatherings, a perfect spot for a family outing.
slides.title: Cutter's Grove

widgets.html:
Stevens Square

In the heart of Princeville is Stevens Square, a city block-sized park that offers a downtown retreat for a picnic lunch or a lazy afternoon with friends or family. This park is centered around Princeville’s signature gazebo.

Read More

slides.description: In the heart of Princeville is Stevens Square, a city block-sized park that offers a downtown retreat for a picnic lunch or a lazy afternoon with friends or family. This park is centered around Princeville’s signature gazebo.
slides.title: StevensSquare

widgets.html:
Troutman Park

A community park located on the northern edge of Princeville. The park includes a JFL field, ball field, walking path, concession stand/restrooms, and a picnic pavilion. Troutman Park is also a member of the Peoria Riverfront Museum Community Solar System.

Read More

The Akron Townhouse School allows children and adults alike to take a step back in time and participate in a day in the life of a student in the early 1900’s.

City of Washington

Historic Washington is a wonderful place to slow down and enjoy life. Immerse yourself in the unique and charming shopping opportunities on historic Washington Square. Grab a drink at Faire, a delicious cafe located in a renovated bank from the 1800s.

Visit Five Points Washington, a community center for all ages. In addition to the fitness and aquatic center, Five Points offers banquet and meeting space and theater. The event calendar is always filled with exciting, nationally recognized acts you won’t want to miss.

Washington invites you to come and enjoy the quaint shops, flavorsome dining, and relaxed atmosphere of their historic downtown square. Enjoy ice cream and popcorn from Holland’s Caramel Corn, and buy a unique gift at Sentimental Journey.

Make sure to plan for a wine tasting at Tres Rojas Winery or make a stop at the popular The Blend coffee shop before trying out your favorite new bike at Russell's Cycling and Fitness store.

Washington Good Neighbor Days happens every summer throughout the city, with a variety of festival-related events.

Fulton County

Surrounded by over 30 miles of Illinois River and 40 miles of the Spoon River, Fulton County offers an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The Spoon River Scenic Drive starts at Medina, carving a wide scenic valley through Fulton County as it flows from London Mills to the south and east where it joins the Illinois River near the southeastern corner of the county. 

Since 1968, Fulton County has hosted the Scenic Drive’s Fall Festival on the Spoon River Drive the first two full weekends in October. Are you curious about what life was like on the Illinois River Valley 12,000 years ago? Head over to Dickson Mounds Museum which is a branch of the Illinois State Museum and a National Historic Site. Miles of country trails can be hiked in Lewistown and then topped off with the perfect vintage at Native Trails Winery. Finish your stay in Fulton County at The Canton Harvester Inn which is a four-story luxury boutique hotel.

Fulton County is also home to Big Horse Vineyards in Lewistown. Enjoy a bottle of wine, sit back and relax while taking in the scenic views of the vineyard, farm and the majestic horses. Stop by Emiquon National Wildlife Refuge for more beautiful scenic views, recreational activities and wildlife watching. Also in Lewistown is Orchard Hill Farm, the perfect destination for families to shop for fresh fall items such as apple cider donuts and enjoy activities like the corn maze and barrel train. Orchard Hill Farm also has a series of events throughout the fall season.

Visit Canton lake for an abundance of nature views. Enjoy a day of fishing, boating and hiking or check out their lake view observation deck. Big Creek Park is another popular destination in Canton with a pool, walking trails and many recreational activities. Stop by Elm St Café for a tasty all day breakfast or a casual lunch or dinner.

Things to Do in Fulton County

Spoon River Valley Scenic Drive

Big Horse Vineyards

Orchard Hill Farm

Dickson Mounds Museum

Marshall County

Located directly north of Peoria County is a county that is full of rich Illinois history but is quickly evolving to rival the amenities of big cities. In the heart of Marshall County is Lacon, a thriving community with a close tie to President Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln visited the county on at least four occasions and both Lincoln and Douglas visited Lacon in 1854 and were set to both make speeches in front of the courthouse, though neither spoke. 

Located in Lacon is Marshall State Fish and Wildlife Area, the perfect spot for adventuring, picnicking, camping, fishing, hiking and hunting. View wildlife such as waterfowl, great blue herons and bald eagles in their natural habitats. If you're a golf fan, stop by the Timber Ridge Golf Club in Lacon for a 9-hole course.

Located in the center of the town is Marshall County Historical Society, a museum where you and your family can discover the history of Marshall County through intriguing exhibits and hands-on experiences. History is also all around you at The Coffee Hub which is located on the main floor of a building that is 100 years old. Enjoy locally roasted coffee with homemade treats, ice cream from Uncle Bob’s in Eureka and check out the local art that lines the wall. Open seven days a week, there is plenty of time to visit, relax and enjoy a cup of coffee while visiting Marshall County. 

Grab a drink at Zoomiez on the Water. a local favorite riverfront bar located on the Lacon Marina. Don't miss their live music events!

Marshall County’s Old Settlers Festival will be celebrating its 151st year in 2021! This annual county festival is held at the marina in Lacon and features a unique festival theme each year. The festival also features a 5K and 10K, parade, stage entertainment and cruise in.

Things to Do in Marshall County

Emiquon National Wildlife Refuge

Marshall County Historical Society

Lacon Bridge

The Coffee Hub

Mason County

Calling all outdoor lovers! Mason County is an outdoor lover’s haven. Chautauqua National Wildlife Refuge in Havana, one of four Wildlife refuges in the state of Illinois, is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Services and is also ADA accessible. This refuge is packed with beautiful wetlands, woods and wildlife. 

Discover historic Havana where you can spend the day shopping local boutiques, enjoy a beautiful riverfront park and historic architecture. On the first Friday from May-October, downtown historic Havana comes alive with evening shopping, live music, art shows, demonstrations and much more! The shops and boutiques offer evening shopping, food and drink specials in the local restaurants and free live music. Havana also hosts a Saturday morning Farmers’ Market through the summer and start of fall where you can shop fresh treats and produce. Don't miss Havana's annual Oktoberfest, a festival full of food, music and things to do that the whole family will love.

If you're looking for a good meal, Tall Timbers Marina in Havana is a fun stop for burgers, hot dogs and cold drinks. Visit the marina on foot or by boat, and enjoy you food with the relaxing sights and sounds of the Illinois river. Also in Havana is Rockwell Mound Park, a welcoming landmark of Native American culture. The park consists of a playground as well as traditional Indian burial mounds. 

Mason County is also home to Sand Ridge State Forest, a conservation area filled with native oak-hickory woodland, pine plantations, open fields, grasslands and sand prairies. Enjoy unspoiled nature in a beautiful and unique setting. Sand Ridge State Forest is ideal for a number of recreational activities including archery, camping, hiking, hunting, cross country skiing and geocaching. The forest also has snowmobile, mountain biking and equestrian trails.

Things to Do in Mason County

Havana's First Fridays

Sand Ridge State Forest

Havana's Farmers' Market

Rockwell Mound Park

Peoria County

Known as the Heart of Illinois, Peoria County lies on the west side of the Illinois River in halfway between Chicago, IL and St. Louis, MO. Known for having big city amenities in a small-town feel Peoria Country has 15 cities and villages for you to discover. Read on to learn how Peoria County is brimming with possibility- with connections and relationships found around every corner of this tight-knit community.

City of Peoria

Rising up from the banks of the Illinois River lies Peoria–a city built from a deep-rooted history in manufacturing, agriculture, and whiskey.

Stark with US!
Stark County Manufacturers

Stark County

On your way out of Peoria County, you’ll run across Tanner’s Orchard, located in Speer on the border of Peoria and Stark Counties. Since 1947, four generations of the Tanner family have welcomed people from all over to an amazing farm experience. This 80-acre farm has become a family destination with a bakery serving noon lunches, a large country farm market with the best apple cider donuts you will ever taste, pick your own apples and pumpkins, a corn maze and the Back 40 Fun Acres with farm animals. 

Stretching through Stark County is Rock Island Trail, a 26-mile long public rail trail filled with prairie grasses, beautiful views and uninterrupted nature. The trail is used for a number of recreational activities including hiking, biking, camping and skiing. Bring your family out for a day on the trail and enjoy the beauty of nature. Just north of Peoria on Rt. 40 also in Stark County, you’ll discover the historic Pony Truss Steel Bridge, a perfect spot to stretch your legs and enjoy the views.

Farther north in Wyoming sits the beautifully restored Paramount Theater. Originally opened in 1934, this theater has closed and reopened multiple times throughout its history. Now, this old school theatre hosts events year-round and is a performance venue bringing culture alive to Stark County. Toulon is where Stark County’s Courthouse and Jail is located, and it is the oldest operating courthouse in the state of Illinois. Built back in 1857, the courthouse has been renovated throughout the years but the original structure remains the same. 

Also in Wyoming is A Few of My Favorite Things Flower & Gift Shop. This specialty store is a fun stop if you're in the area and in the mood for some shopping, and sells beautiful flowers as well as many specialty gift items. 

After a day in Stark County, head out to Catalpa Grove for tasty burgers, steaks, pasta, chicken, wraps, tacos and more. Catalpa Grove is a delicious bar and grill serving up American food that the whole family will enjoy. Their huge menu ensures you’ll find something you love, try out the hamburger horseshoe or the fried calamari and don’t forget to ask for one of their special sauces!

Things to Do in Stark County

Tanner's Orchard

Rock Island Trail

A Few of My Favorite Things Gift Shop

Catalpa Grove

slides.title: A Few of My Favorite Things Gift Shop

Tazewell County

Located on the East side of the Illinois River lies Tazewell County, one of the Heart of Illinois tri-county counterparts. These communities continue to offer the city amenities known for in Peoria but off stunning countryside views. Fifteen communities call Tazewell County home and we encourage you to discover them all. 

A quick drive across the Illinois River takes you to East Peoria, where entertainment is never in short supply. Home to the famous Festival of Lights, this marvel of engineering creates giant floats and scenes made entirely of Christmas lights! Not only is East Peoria home to the beautiful East Peoria RiverFront and RiverFront Park but there is plenty to discover at East Peoria's most popular destinations including Bass Pro Shops, Par-A-Dice Hotel Casino, ROC Ice Cream & Mini Golf and more!

Founded in 1825, historic Washington is a wonderful place to slow down and enjoy life. Immerse yourself in the unique and charming shopping opportunities on the historic Washington Square and grab a bite to eat at The Blacksmith, a delicious eatery located in a renovated bank from the 1800s. Visit Tres Rojas Winery for some tasty wine, or check out Five Points Washington for events and live music.

The Marigold Capital of the World, Pekin is the largest community in Tazewell County and is filled with unique attractions to explore. Home to the world’s largest sundial, you can spend the day in Mineral Springs Park paddle boating on the lagoon. Enjoy world-class golf courses, Pekin Paintball Park, disc golf, bowling and Dragonland Water Park. Take a stroll downtown on historic Court Street and enjoy an abundance of shopping and delicious dining!

Welcome to the Pumpkin Capital of the World! Morton is home to Nestle USA, maker of the world’s top-selling canned pumpkin, Libby’s Pumpkin. What holiday dinner is complete without a pumpkin pie made from Libby’s? This quaint, peaceful village is rapidly building its image as an up-and-coming foodie destination. Check out Seasons Gastropub for a delicious menu and endless beer or Four30 Scones for mouth-watering baked treats.

Things to Do in Tazewell County

Par-A-Dice Casino

Tres Rojas Winery

Mineral Springs Park Pavillion on the Lagoon

Pekin Park

Morton Square Park

Five Points Washington

The Levee District

Jonah's Seafood House & 2601 Oyster Bar

slides.title: Mineral Springs Park Pavillion on the Lagoon

Woodford County

Woodford County is the largest producer of organic farming in the state of Illinois! While these delicious fruits and veggies are sold throughout the country, you can pick through the freshest batches at our local farmer’s markets. Due to higher elevation and flat plains of farmland, locals claim Woodford county is home to the most beautiful sunsets in the area. 

You can catch one of those sunsets at Metamora Fields Golf Club. Metamora Fields, an exclusively public facility, offers a challenging yet playable experience for golfers of all levels. In the warm seasons, check out Metamora swimming pool, a great destination for kids with water slides. Go on an adventure at Black Partridge Park, which has an extensive mountain bike and trail system filled with fun and thrill. Enjoy the beauty of nature, a kids playground and many pavilions where you can relax and enjoy your surroundings. If you're in need of a coffee break, stop by Eli's coffee shop for tasty coffee flavors and treats. 

In the mood for something sweet after your round of golf? Uncle Bob’s Homemade Ice Cream opened in July 1980 at the Heart of Illinois Fair and now has a permanent location in Eureka. Uncle Bob’s works with local dairies, bakeries and suppliers to ensure their product is fresh and homemade, plus you can even buy quarts of your favorite flavors at local grocery stores! 

Also nestled in Eureka is President Ronald Reagan’s alma mater, Eureka College. This liberal arts and science institution is affiliated with the Christian Church and offers an intimate college experience. Located on campus is The Ronald Reagan Museum and Peace Garden in honor of the United States 40th President. The museum collection houses over 10,000 items from President Reagan’s Eureka College student days, movie and TV career, the governorship of California and his two terms as president. 

Woodford County is also home to Germantown Hills, a blend of small town living with big city convenience. Be sure to check out Buttermilk Café for a delicious breakfast. Kouri's Grill and Bar is another local food favorite. 

Enjoy an escape from reality by visiting Spring Bay, known for its untouched wilderness, serene beaches and peaceful parks. Spring bay is the perfect spot to float along creeks and lakes and for boating on the Illinois River. Treat yourself to a stay at Sankoty Lakes, a world-class wilderness retreat that offers many relaxation and recreation experiences.

Things to Do in Woodford County

Eureka College

Metamora Fields Golf Club

Black Partridge Park

Sankoty Lakes
